unnormalised: What are the key differences between Sections 302 and 304 of the IPC?
normalised: What are the key differences between Sections three hundred and two and three hundred and four of the I-P-C?

unnormalised: Sections 302 and 304 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) are critical in defining culpable homicide, but they differ significantly in their implications. Sec. 302 deals with murder, prescribing the punishment for whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. A crucial element for invoking Sec 302 is proving intent to cause death or knowledge that the act is likely to cause death, as seen in the case of State of Maharashtra v. Ashok Sharma. The severity of the punishment reflects the gravity of the offence, as murder involves a higher degree of culpability and malice.
normalised: Sections three hundred and two and three hundred and four of the Indian Penal Code (I-P-C) are critical in defining culpable homicide, but they differ significantly in their implications. Section three hundred and two deals with murder, prescribing the punishment for whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine. A crucial element for invoking Section three hundred and two is proving intent to cause death or knowledge that the act is likely to cause death, as seen in the case of State of Maharashtra versus Ashok Sharma. The severity of the punishment reflects the gravity of the offence, as murder involves a higher degree of culpability and malice.

unnormalised: In contrast, Section 304 addresses culpable homicide not amounting to murder. It is bifurcated into two parts: Part I deals with acts done with the intention of causing death or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, prescribing a punishment of imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 yrs, along with a fine. Part II covers acts done with the knowledge that they are likely to cause death but without any intention to cause death or cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, prescribing imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to 10 years, or with fine, or with both. For example, consider a situation where someone hits another person on the head with an object, knowing it could cause death, but without the direct intent to kill; this might fall under Sec. 304 Part II.
normalised: In contrast, Section three hundred and four addresses culpable homicide not amounting to murder. It is bifurcated into two parts: Part one deals with acts done with the intention of causing death or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, prescribing a punishment of imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to ten years, along with a fine. Part two covers acts done with the knowledge that they are likely to cause death but without any intention to cause death or cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, prescribing imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both. For example, consider a situation where someone hits another person on the head with an object, knowing it could cause death, but without the direct intent to kill; this might fall under Section three hundred and four Part two.

unnormalised: The key distinction lies in the mental state of the offender. Sec 302 requires a deliberate intention to cause death or the knowledge that the act is almost certain to result in death, whereas Sec. 304 involves a lesser degree of intention or knowledge.
